top.name: Qui
top.review:
What’s a sellout? Someone who forsakes their uniqueness and does what is expected or demanded of them for financial gain or vanity. Basically: taking the easy way out.

Paul Qui is no sellout.

After destroying the competition on “Top Chef” in 2012, the former Uchiko executive chef could have opened his own highly visible take on the massively popular restaurant, played to expectations, sat back and counted his money.

Instead he followed his passion. Qui opened a restaurant on a bar-lined part of still-developing East Sixth Street, the stomping grounds of many service industry workers. The stark white building echoes a blank slate or a lab coat indicative of experimentation. He didn’t even put his famous name in an easily noticeable spot.

Returning to the Filipino roots of his mother’s family and nodding to global influences he picked up in travels following his sudden fame, Qui developed an initial menu that included Filipino pork blood stew, Spanish-inspired hen rice, and an artful dish of vegetables that paid homage to French chef Michel Bras.

Then, after about a year in business, Qui decided to scrap the a la carte menu for a seven-course tasting menu. There is still evidence of the original menu, though with minor tweaks. The marcona almond gazpacho, poured into a mug ringed with foie gras that looks like pencil shavings, now has a silkier and smoother consistency. The pork blood dinuguan has gone from a bowl of stew with gnocchi to a velvety blanket for grilled maitake mushrooms.

Qui has not left his seafood past completely behind. Chefs, who deliver the food they prepare to each table, sear pink pieces of albacore on sizzling mini-logs of white oak tableside, the mildly fatty fish absorbing the fragrant smoke and the herbal mojo verde made with garlic, parsley and cilantro.

Meals at Qui will likely introduce diners to new flavors. A recent dinner marked my first encounter with coconut vinegar, which bathed tender chicken thigh meat pulled from the bone, as well as chardonnay vinegar, used in the albacore dish.

The creativity at Qui extends to its exceptional bar program that preceded a recent glass of bourbon and apricot brandy with palate-cleansing basil-seed “caviar.”

The tiny bar may offer the best solo dining option at Qui, as you can order the tasting menu or select from a bar menu (reserved for patio diners) that includes chicken and pork kebabs and Filipino ceviche.

Qui recently added a ticketed chef’s table option that includes dozens of dishes and gives the chef and his accomplished team even greater range to express their ingenuity. The evolutionary changes at the restaurant during its first 15 months in business are illustrative of Qui’s culinary curiosity, adaptability and adherence to his unique vision.

mexican.name: Azul Tequila
mexican.chatter: You can hopscotch on the menu between Tex-Mex staples (chicken flautas) and interior Mexican (mole poblano).

mexican.name: Fonda San Miguel
mexican.chatter: Fonda San Miguel introduced Austinites to the idea that Mexican food didn’t need a “Tex” in front of it and that you shouldn’t always expect it to be cheap.

mexican.name: Las Palomas
mexican.chatter: I like to order the house special (a relleno stuffed with ground beef and pork, raisins, almonds and pecans) served in a zippy tomato sauce at this reliable Westlake area restaurant.

mexican.name: Licha's Cantina
mexican.chatter: Longtime Austin industry veteran Daniel Brooks brought the form and flavors of his native Mexican street food (tlacoyos, huitlacoche) to this charming rustic bungalow in East Austin.

mexican.name: Matt's El Rancho
mexican.chatter: An Austin institution offering Mexican food in a sprawling but welcoming and festive space.

mexican.name: Polvos
mexican.chatter: The best shrimp fajitas in South Austin, a diverse salsa bar and choriqueso keep me coming back.

mexican.name: Tamale House East
mexican.chatter: The grandchildren of the original Tamale House founders carry on the family tradition with wet migas and popular breakfast tacos.

chinese.name: Rice Bowl Café
chinese.chatter: From the pan-fried green onion pancakes to springy salt-and-pepper squid, it’s hard to go wrong at this Chinese restaurant.

chinese.name: Szechuan House
chinese.chatter: Ignore the Americanized offerings and head for the Szechuan specialties like wonton in red oil and spicy fish. The lamb with cumin will taste familiar to fans of Mexican food.

friedchicken.name: Gus’s Fried Chicken
friedchicken.chatter: The star here is in the name – crunchy and tender fried chicken with a little spice kick.

friedchicken.name: Lucy's
friedchicken.chatter: In addition to solid fried chicken, try the grilled oysters and boudin blanc.

japanese.name: Kome
japanese.chatter: The sushi from the husband-and-wife team that started in a trailer deserves notice, but the grilled and fried izakaya options help set this place apart from other sushi restaurants of its ilk.

japanese.name: Ramen Tatsu-Ya
japanese.chatter: Deep, rich, sumptuous bowls of fatty soup draw lines out the door.

french.name: Arro
french.chatter: French bistro classics like roasted duck and pan-seared frog legs in brown butter at this hip restaurant that has a great wine list.

french.name: Chez Nous
french.chatter: Rich dishes like duck with apricot compote and trout meunière make up the heart of the menu at this retreat from the Sixth Street madness.

burgers.name: Casino El Camino
burgers.chatter: This dark Sixth Street bar with rock ‘n’ roll grills fat, juicy burgers.

burgers.name: Crown and Anchor
burgers.chatter: Make sure you order a double (add bacon) from this campus-area stalwart.

burgers.name: Hopdoddy
burgers.chatter: Quality ingredients and thoughtful flavor profiles make for long lines at the two Austin locations.

burgers.name: Hopfields
burgers.chatter: Funky Camembert cheese tops the juicy burger at this French-inspired gastropub that has an excellent beer selection.

burgers.name: P. Terry’s
burgers.chatter: Patrick Terry has created a mini-empire with his retro burger restaurants thanks to good ingredients, friendly service and competitive prices. Better than In-N-Out Burger. Period.

burgers.name: Top Notch Hamburgers
burgers.chatter: New ownership was wise not to change the aesthetics at this classic car-hop spot that was featured in “Dazed and Confused.” A charcoal grill gives the burgers a nostalgic backyard-burger flavor.

indian.name: Asiana
indian.chatter: Hit the lunch buffet to get a sampling of the wide array of offerings, including chicken tikka masala and aromatic lamb rogan josh.

indian.name: Clay Pit
indian.chatter: Clay Pit serves up a lively environment and a roster of specialties like khuroos-e-tursh (mushroom and spinach-stuffed chicken in a sweet cashew-almond cream sauce).

indian.name: Swad
indian.chatter: A flavorful (and at times spicy) way to get your vegetables.

indian.name: Tarka
indian.chatter: The Clay Pit’s fast-casual little brother serves familiar curries like korma and vindaloo as well as unique options like sandwiches served inside naan bread.

indian.name: Whip In
indian.chatter: What started as a convenience store in 1986 has evolved into a brew pub and wine bar that serves traditional Indian vegetable dishes and Texas-Indian hybrids like a Frito pie with cilantro chutney.

pizza.name: The Backspace
pizza.chatter: Neapolitan pies from Parkside chef Shawn Cirkiel’s small restaurant that also serves charcuterie and a nice roster of antipasti.

pizza.name: East Side PIes
pizza.chatter: Cracker crust farm-to-pizza at three locations around town. Get the Girther (avocado, blue cheese and roasted onions) and add bacon.

pizza.name: Home Slice Pizza
pizza.chatter: The best New York City-style slices in Austin.

pizza.name: House Pizzeria
pizza.chatter: A nice mix of crunch and chew in these pizzas with great toppings like port reduction and Stilton cheese.

pizza.name: Little Deli and Pizzeria
pizza.chatter: Excellent New Jersey-style pies from this quaint little deli that feels like a step back in time.

pizza.name: Salvation Pizza
pizza.chatter: Excellent New Jersey-style pies from this quaint little deli that feels like a step back in time.

barbecue.name: La Barbecue
barbecue.chatter: The best barbecue in Austin. Start with the brisket and go from there.

barbecue.name: J. Mueller Meat Co.
barbecue.chatter: Old-school barbecue cook John Mueller’s brisket bark is as fierce as his half-joking snarl.

barbecue.name: Micklethwait Craft Meats
barbecue.chatter: Tom Micklethwait’s East Austin trailer specializes in inventive and flavorful sausage and makes surprisingly good desserts.

barbecue.name: Brown’s Bar-B-Que
barbecue.chatter: This South Lamar trailer smokes some of the best chicken and pork ribs in town.

barbecue.name: Kerlin BBQ
barbecue.chatter: This trailer serves solid brisket and a nice blue cheese-twist on cole slaw.

barbecue.name: Freedmen’s
barbecue.chatter: With a historic old building, handsome bar and outdoor courtyard, this is the best restaurant space for barbecue in Austin.

breakfast.name: Counter Café
breakfast.chatter: The cakes-and-eggs dish at this diner uses crab cakes for a refreshing alternative to traditional breakfast fare.

breakfast.name: Kerbey Lane
breakfast.chatter: An Austin original that has been interested in conscientious sourcing since before it was popular.

breakfast.name: Magnolia Cafe
breakfast.chatter: Funky and fun, this place is a testament to the fact that pancakes and omelets taste good any time of the day or night.

italian.name: Andiamo Ristorante
italian.chatter: Authentic Italian in North Austin with a family-owned vibe and travelogue photos on the wall of the Italian peninsula. Try the homemade ravioli.

italian.name: Asti
italian.chatter: Neighborhood Italian with a sophisticated touch in the middle of Hyde Park. Get the rigatoni and add sausage.

italian.name: Cipollina
italian.chatter: Handmade pastas and Neapolitan pizzas are standouts at this charming Clarksville spot.

italian.name: Enoteca
italian.chatter: Vespaio’s cute little sister, Enoteca makes very good pizzas, piping hot pastas and solid Italian desserts.

italian.name: Olive & June
italian.chatter: The best handmade pasta in town and a nice selection of well-executed small plates are the draws at this multi-tiered treehouse restaurant.

italian.name: Vespaio
italian.chatter: A classy spin on Americanized Italian, Vespaio has been a long-standing staple on South Congress thanks to dishes like their lasagna and cioppino.

hotels.name: The Carillon
hotels.chatter: One of the city’s most underrated restaurants serves New American cuisine, from seared scallops to grilled quail. It also offers good value, with four-course dinners for $50.

hotels.name: Driskill Grill
hotels.chatter: A throwback piece of Austin dining culture that too often goes overlooked.

hotels.name: Trace
hotels.chatter: Trace does an admirable job battling the stereotypes that often come with being a hotel restaurant. Service is polite and measured in the mod space colored with shades of black and white, and the menu is always fresh and engaging.

hotels.name: Trio at the Four Seasons
hotels.chatter: You needn’t check into a room at the Four Seasons to be treated like a VIP at Trio. The accommodating and exceedingly polite staff anticipates your needs in guiding you through the restaurant’s steak-centric menu and wine list, composed by sommelier Mark Sayre, one of Trio’s finest ambassadors.
